content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays two main pieces of adipose tissue, which likely represent a pericolic fat dissection. Within these tissue fragments, there are several nodular structures of varying sizes. These are consistent with lymph nodes. The most prominent structure is a large, basophilic (dark purple) and well-circumscribed node in the lower right, which is highly suspicious for being a lymph node completely replaced by metastatic tumor. Another smaller, but still distinct, lymph node is visible in the upper left tissue fragment. Other smaller potential lymph nodes and vascular structures are also present. The overall impression is of a lymph node dissection for staging colorectal cancer, with at least one grossly positive node.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my goal is to identify and examine every lymph node to accurately determine the N stage (number of positive nodes). While the large node in the lower right is almost certainly positive, I must systematically screen all tissue for other, smaller nodes. The area highlighted by the green box contains a small, basophilic (cellular) aggregate within the fat, which is suspicious for being another lymph node. Therefore, I am zooming in to confirm if it is indeed a lymph node and to meticulously search for any evidence of metastatic carcinoma, no matter how small. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to identify all positive lymph nodes, not just the obviously involved ones. The green box is placed on a small, basophilic aggregate in the upper-left tissue fragment. This area represents a potential small lymph node or a lymphoid aggregate that must be carefully examined. Even if a case has a grossly positive node, it's crucial to assess all other nodes for micrometastases or isolated tumor cells, as the total number of positive nodes is a key prognostic factor (part of the N stage). I am zooming in to confirm if this is lymphoid tissue and to meticulously search for any atypical epithelial cells (metastatic carcinoma). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The green box is centered on the first lymph node from the top left. At low power, this node contains a focal, dense, and basophilic (dark purple) area that appears distinct from the surrounding lymphoid tissue. This appearance is highly suspicious for a metastatic deposit, which often disrupts the normal architecture of the lymph node. I would zoom into this specific area to examine the cytology of these cells and confirm whether they are malignant epithelial cells, thus confirming this as a positive lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the larger, more suspicious lymph node located in the bottom-right tissue fragment. The lymph node architecture appears almost completely effaced and replaced by a basophilic tumor. This is a critical area to examine to confirm the presence and extent of metastasis. The purpose of zooming in is to verify the malignant nature of the cells and assess for features like extranodal extension, which is crucial for staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a portion of a lymph node surrounded by mature adipose tissue. There is a dense infiltrate of small, dark, round cells, which are lymphocytes, confirming the presence of lymphoid tissue. I can also see fibrotic stroma (pink, wavy collagen) and a mixed inflammatory infiltrate, including some eosinophils. There are no definitive malignant cells, such as atypical glands or large pleomorphic epithelial cells, in this specific field of view. The impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node. The entire node must be examined to definitively rule out a micrometastasis, but this particular area appears negative for tumor.
This is ROI 2. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see mature adipose tissue characterized by large, empty-appearing adipocytes. Interspersed within the fat are fibrous septa containing collections of small, mature-looking lymphocytes. These lymphoid cells are arranged in loose and dense aggregates. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, clusters of malignant epithelial cells, or single abnormal cells. The lymphocytes present appear benign. My impression is that this is perinodal adipose tissue with benign lymphoid aggregates, and there is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in this specific field of view.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At high magnification, I see a cellular proliferation of atypical cells infiltrating adipose tissue and residual lymphoid tissue. The cells are pleomorphic, with spindled to epithelioid shapes, eosinophilic cytoplasm, and irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei. They are arranged in disorganized sheets and fascicles. There is an associated inflammatory infiltrate, including lymphocytes, and some areas of hemorrhage. This morphology is not characteristic of lymphoid cells and is diagnostic of metastatic carcinoma. Therefore, this is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-magnification view confirms the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma. I can see irregular, back-to-back, and cribriform glands lined by malignant epithelial cells. These cells show significant nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and irregular nuclear membranes. There is abundant eosinophilic necrotic debris within the glandular lumens, often referred to as 'dirty necrosis,' which is highly characteristic of colorectal adenocarcinoma. The tumor is surrounded by a desmoplastic stromal reaction and a notable inflammatory infiltrate. My impression is a lymph node completely replaced by metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with a colorectal primary.
